>>>>> "Alex" == Alex Jacobson <alex@...> writes:

    Alex> REST pretends that we can talk about transferring
    Alex> representations without talking about being able to talk
    Alex> unambiguously about what is represented.  

How is this different from Content-Type? If I ask for a GET with
Content-Type V-Card isn't that unambigious? Or GET with Content-Type
audio/wav or audio/mp3, isn't that clear?


    Alex> Content-Negotiation Content-negotiation exacerbates the
    Alex> problem above.  It is particularly incompatible with
    Alex> PUT/POST because the server has no way to tell the client
    Alex> what types may be PUT/POST and REST provides no way to
    Alex> understand what was meant when a client does so.

A GET with Content-Type rest/content-types can solve this perhaps?

A server can always accepts content types it understands and issue a
4xx when it doesn't of course.


I'm afraid that meta modeling doesn't solve any problem. The next
problem is usually the meta meta model of that. And the meta meta meta
model of that.

-- 
Regards,

Berend. (-:
